--- title: "When Do Networks Create Value?" subtitle: "Social Capital, Brokerage, and Business Performance" author: "SMM638 Network Analytics" format: revealjs: theme: default slide-number: true transition: slide chalkboard: true multiplex: false css: ../../slideshow-theme.css code-fold: true code-summary: "" --- ## The Leading Question ::: {.callout-important icon=false style="font-size: 1.4em;"} When do networks create value for individuals and organizations? ::: This question drives network theory's investigation into how structural position translates into tangible outcomes. ## A Theoretical Framework ::: {style="margin-top: 40px;"} | | **Social Capital** | **Social Homogeneity** | |--------------------------|---------------------------------------|------------------------| | **Network Flow** | [Capitalization (Value Creation)]{style="background: #d4edda; padding: 4px 8px; border-radius: 4px;"} | Contagion | | **Network Architecture** | Coordination | Adaptation (Network Change) | ::: ::: {style="margin-top: 40px; text-align: center; color: #555;"} Our focus today: How network position creates value through **social capital** mechanisms ::: ::: aside Source: Scott (2011), SAGE Handbook of Social Network Analysis, p. 47 ::: ## Two Theories of Network Value :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="48%"} ::: {.card style="background: #1a5f3c; color: white; padding: 25px; border-radius: 8px; height: 320px;"} ### [ðŸŒ‰]{style="font-size: 1.5em;"} Bridging Social Capital {style="color: white; border-bottom: none;"} Sparse networks bring value through access to **diverse information** and new opportunities. ::: {style="background: rgba(255,255,255,0.15); padding: 12px; border-radius: 4px; margin-top: 20px;"} **Mechanism:** Network Brokerage **Key scholar:** Ron Burt ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="4%"} ::: ::: {.column width="48%"} ::: {.card style="background: #722f37; color: white; padding: 25px; border-radius: 8px; height: 320px;"} ### [ðŸ”—]{style="font-size: 1.5em;"} Bonding Social Capital {style="color: white; border-bottom: none;"} Dense networks create value by fostering **trust** and enabling cooperation. ::: {style="background: rgba(255,255,255,0.15); padding: 12px; border-radius: 4px; margin-top: 20px;"} **Mechanism:** Network Closure **Key scholar:** James Coleman ::: ::: ::: :::: ## {#section-bonding data-menu-title="Section: Bonding" background-color="#722f37"} ::: {style="padding: 60px;"} [PART ONE]{style="color: rgba(255,255,255,0.6); font-size: 0.8em; letter-spacing: 3px;"} # Bonding Social Capital {style="color: white; font-family: Georgia, serif; margin-top: 10px;"} ::: {style="width: 80px; height: 4px; background: #c9a227; margin: 20px 0;"} ::: [How dense networks create value through closure and trust]{style="color: rgba(255,255,255,0.8); font-size: 1.2em;"} ::: ## What is Network Closure? :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="55%"} ::: {.definition style="background: #f8f4f4; border: 2px solid #722f37; border-radius: 6px; padding: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px;"} **Definition** Network closure is the tendency for a network to present **direct ties between pairs of nodes**, creating dense, interconnected structures. ::: **Key insight:** When your friends know each other, information travels in closed loops. This creates an environment where: - Reputation effects can operate - Social norms can be enforced - Trust can be established and maintained ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} library(igraph) library(ggraph) # Create a fully connected network g <- make_full_graph(5) V(g)$name <- LETTERS[1:5] ggraph(g, layout = "circle") + geom_edge_link(color = "gray60", width = 1.2) + geom_node_point(size = 12, color = "#c9a227") + geom_node_text(aes(label = name), color = "white", fontface = "bold", size = 4) + theme_void() + labs(title = "High-Closure Network") + theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, color = "#722f37", face = "bold")) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](slideshow_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){fig-align='center' width=384} ::: ::: ::: :::: ## How Closure Creates Value :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="33%"} ::: {.card style="background: linear-gradient(135deg, #722f37 0%, #8b3a43 100%); color: white; padding: 20px; border-radius: 8px; height: 220px;"} ### ðŸ›¡ï¸ Trust & Cooperation {style="color: white; font-size: 0.9em; border-bottom: none;"} Dense networks enable reciprocity. If A cheats B, mutual friend C will learn and sanction A. ::: ::: ::: {.column width="33%"} ::: {.card style="background: linear-gradient(135deg, #722f37 0%, #8b3a43 100%); color: white; padding: 20px; border-radius: 8px; height: 220px;"} ### ðŸ“¢ Reputation Effects {style="color: white; font-size: 0.9em; border-bottom: none;"} Bad behavior spreads quickly. Cheating becomes "unbearable when mutual friends uncover the deceit." ::: ::: ::: {.column width="33%"} ::: {.card style="background: linear-gradient(135deg, #722f37 0%, #8b3a43 100%); color: white; padding: 20px; border-radius: 8px; height: 220px;"} ### âš–ï¸ Norm Enforcement {style="color: white; font-size: 0.9em; border-bottom: none;"} Closed networks establish and enforce shared expectations, reducing uncertainty in transactions. ::: ::: :::: ::: {.callout-tip appearance="minimal" style="margin-top: 30px; background: #f5f0f0; border-left: 4px solid #722f37;"} *"Embedded ties protect the integrity of social and economic transactions."* â€” Coleman's view of social capital ::: ## Measuring Closure: Clustering Coefficient :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} For a node $i$ with degree $k_i$, the **clustering coefficient** is: $$C_i = \frac{2L_i}{k_i(k_i - 1)}$$ where $L_i$ = number of links between the $k_i$ neighbors of node $i$
**Interpretation:** What proportion of my friends' possible friendships actually exist? ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} library(igraph) library(ggraph) library(patchwork) # Three examples of clustering # C = 0 g1 <- graph_from_edgelist(matrix(c(1,2, 1,3, 1,4), ncol=2, byrow=TRUE), directed=FALSE) V(g1)$color <- c("#722f37", "#c9a227", "#c9a227", "#c9a227") # C = 1/3 g2 <- graph_from_edgelist(matrix(c(1,2, 1,3, 1,4, 2,3), ncol=2, byrow=TRUE), directed=FALSE) V(g2)$color <- c("#722f37", "#c9a227", "#c9a227", "#c9a227") # C = 1 g3 <- graph_from_edgelist(matrix(c(1,2, 1,3, 1,4, 2,3, 3,4, 2,4), ncol=2, byrow=TRUE), directed=FALSE) V(g3)$color <- c("#722f37", "#c9a227", "#c9a227", "#c9a227") p1 <- ggraph(g1, layout = "star") + geom_edge_link(color = "gray50", width = 1) + geom_node_point(aes(color = I(V(g1)$color)), size = 10) + theme_void() + labs(title = "C = 0") + theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold")) p2 <- ggraph(g2, layout = "star") + geom_edge_link(color = "gray50", width = 1) + geom_node_point(aes(color = I(V(g2)$color)), size = 10) + theme_void() + labs(title = "C = 1/3") + theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold")) p3 <- ggraph(g3, layout = "star") + geom_edge_link(color = "gray50", width = 1) + geom_node_point(aes(color = I(V(g3)$color)), size = 10) + theme_void() + labs(title = "C = 1") + theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold")) p1 + p2 + p3 ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](slideshow_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){fig-align='center' width=576} ::: ::: [Center node (burgundy) with three neighbors (gold)]{style="font-size: 0.8em; color: #666; text-align: center; display: block;"} ::: :::: ## {#section-bridging data-menu-title="Section: Bridging" background-color="#1a5f3c"} ::: {style="padding: 60px;"} [PART TWO]{style="color: rgba(255,255,255,0.6); font-size: 0.8em; letter-spacing: 3px;"} # Bridging Social Capital {style="color: white; font-family: Georgia, serif; margin-top: 10px;"} ::: {style="width: 80px; height: 4px; background: #c9a227; margin: 20px 0;"} ::: [How sparse networks create value through brokerage and information access]{style="color: rgba(255,255,255,0.8); font-size: 1.2em;"} ::: ## The Strength of Weak Ties :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="55%"} ::: {style="background: #e8f4ec; border-radius: 6px; padding: 18px; margin-bottom: 20px;"} **Granovetter's Discovery (1973)** Job seekers found new positions through **acquaintances** rather than close friendsâ€”people they saw "occasionally" or "rarely." ::: **Why?** Your close friends know what you know. - Strong ties move in overlapping social circles - Information from friends is often *redundant* - Weak ties connect to *different* social worlds - Each acquaintance provides unique, non-overlapping information ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} library(igraph) library(ggraph) # Create a network showing weak ties bridging communities set.seed(42) g <- graph_from_edgelist(matrix(c( 1,2, 1,3, 2,3, # Left cluster (strong ties) 1,4, # Weak tie bridge 4,5, 4,6, 5,6, # Right cluster (strong ties) 1,7, # Another weak tie 7,8, 7,9 # Another cluster ), ncol=2, byrow=TRUE), directed=FALSE) E(g)$type <- c("strong", "strong", "strong", "weak", "strong", "strong", "strong", "weak", "strong", "strong") E(g)$width <- ifelse(E(g)$type == "strong", 2, 1) E(g)$lty <- ifelse(E(g)$type == "strong", 1, 2) V(g)$color <- c("#c9a227", rep("#1a5f3c", 8)) V(g)$size <- c(12, rep(8, 8)) ggraph(g, layout = "fr") + geom_edge_link(aes(width = I(E(g)$width), linetype = I(E(g)$lty)), color = "gray50", alpha = 0.7) + geom_node_point(aes(color = I(V(g)$color), size = I(V(g)$size))) + theme_void() + labs(title = "Weak Ties Bridge Communities") + theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, color = "#1a5f3c", face = "bold")) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](slideshow_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){fig-align='center' width=480} ::: ::: [Dashed lines = weak ties spanning clusters]{style="font-size: 0.8em; color: #666; text-align: center; display: block;"} ::: :::: ::: aside Source: Granovetter (1973), "The Strength of Weak Ties," *American Journal of Sociology* ::: ## Structural Holes: Burt's Framework :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="55%"} ::: {.definition style="background: #e8f4ec; border: 2px solid #1a5f3c; border-radius: 6px; padding: 18px; margin-bottom: 20px;"} **Definition** A **structural hole** is the "empty space" in a network between two sets of nodes that do not otherwise interact closely. ::: **Individuals who span structural holes gain:** :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {style="background: #f5f5f5; padding: 12px; border-radius: 4px;"} **Information** Early access to diverse, non-redundant knowledge ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {style="background: #f5f5f5; padding: 12px; border-radius: 4px;"} **Control** Ability to broker and synthesize across groups ::: ::: :::: ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} library(igraph) library(ggraph) # Create structural hole visualization g <- graph_from_edgelist(matrix(c( 1,2, 1,3, 2,3, 2,4, 3,4, # Left cluster 5,6, 5,7, 6,7, 6,8, 7,8, # Right cluster 4,9, 8,9 # Broker connections ), ncol=2, byrow=TRUE), directed=FALSE) V(g)$color <- c(rep("#722f37", 4), rep("#1a5f3c", 4), "#c9a227") V(g)$size <- c(rep(8, 8), 14) V(g)$label <- c(rep("", 8), "B") coords <- matrix(c( -2, 1, # 1 -2, 0, # 2 -1.5, 0.5, # 3 -1, 0, # 4 2, 1, # 5 2, 0, # 6 1.5, 0.5, # 7 1, 0, # 8 0, 0 # 9 (broker) ), ncol=2, byrow=TRUE) ggraph(g, layout = coords) + geom_edge_link(color = "gray50", width = 1) + geom_node_point(aes(color = I(V(g)$color), size = I(V(g)$size))) + geom_node_text(aes(label = V(g)$label), color = "#1a5f3c", fontface = "bold", size = 5) + theme_void() + labs(title = "Broker Spanning Structural Hole") + theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, color = "#1a5f3c", face = "bold")) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](slideshow_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){fig-align='center' width=480} ::: ::: [Node B spans the gap between two clusters]{style="font-size: 0.8em; color: #666; text-align: center; display: block;"} ::: :::: ::: aside Source: Burt (1992), *Structural Holes: The Social Structure of Competition* ::: ## The Brokerage Advantage ::: {style="display: flex; gap: 20px; margin-top: 30px;"} ::: {.card style="flex: 1; background: #1a5f3c; color: white; padding: 20px; border-radius: 8px;"} ### 1. Non-Redundant Information {style="color: white; border-bottom: none; font-size: 0.95em;"} Brokers access information from multiple, unconnected sourcesâ€”each providing unique knowledge. ::: ::: {.card style="flex: 1; background: #1a5f3c; color: white; padding: 20px; border-radius: 8px;"} ### 2. Early Access {style="color: white; border-bottom: none; font-size: 0.95em;"} Information reaches brokers first because they sit at the intersection of communication flows. ::: ::: {.card style="flex: 1; background: #1a5f3c; color: white; padding: 20px; border-radius: 8px;"} ### 3. Strategic Control {style="color: white; border-bottom: none; font-size: 0.95em;"} Brokers can regulate information flow, synthesize ideas across groups, and create new combinations. ::: ::: ::: {.callout-tip appearance="minimal" style="margin-top: 40px; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #1a5f3c 0%, #2d8a5a 100%); color: white; padding: 20px;"} ðŸ’¡ *"People with networks rich in structural holes have better ideas."* â€” Ron Burt, research on managers at a large electronics company ::: ::: aside Source: Burt (2004), "Structural Holes and Good Ideas," *American Journal of Sociology* ::: ## Measuring Brokerage Position :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {style="background: #e8f4ec; border-radius: 6px; padding: 16px; margin-bottom: 20px;"} ### Betweenness Centrality {style="color: #1a5f3c; border-bottom: none;"} How often does a node lie on the shortest path between others? $$C_B(i) = \sum_{j [Think about your own professional network. Are you more of a **broker** spanning different groups, or embedded in a **closed** cluster of close colleagues?]{style="color: rgba(255,255,255,0.8);"} :::

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
